Maybe reframe the question. What would you be missing if you had children and does that sound like too great a loss? Our child-free friends and acquaintances have activity-rich, full lives that they were not interested in putting on hold for 15 or 20 years. Their lives are filled with travel, hobbies, pets (many pets, in a few cases), careers, groups they belong to and volunteer activities of various kinds, including large-scale community cultural events.
Also how much energy do you have? I know people who do all of the above AND raised children, too. It helps if you do not buy into the current upper middle class notion that children need to be the center of a woman's universe.

Newt Gingrich, now cruising the Greek isles with Wife No. 3 as his campaign staff held hands and jumped overboard, was correct to call the Ryan/Republican Tea Party budget bill "radical" -- before he said he lied and any Democrat who cited his lie was a liar. Mitt Romney once did quite a few things right, before he apologized for them in his "No Apologies" candidate's tou and swore he'd veto any bills that faintly resembled what he used to advocate. All of these men had the potential to bring the Republican party back from the brink of self-destruction and return the nation to a nominal two-party system.

None but Huntsman has showed the guts to do so. So the Republican field of candidates is dominated by pandering wimps who know better & goofballs who think Lexington & Concord are in New Hampshire where Paul Revere warned the British to respect the Second Amendment. The former Republican party is now in the hands of -- Barack Obama -- who has become a Democrat in Name Only, and what passes for the current Republican party best resembles the John Birch Society, an arm of the NRA or the second generation "Moral Majority" of the Jerry Falwell Gang -- or some scary combination thereof.

The New Hampshire motto may be "Live Free or Die," but there are still some normal Republicans left in the state. Let's see if they can prevail against the tide of radical right-wing fantasy that has taken hold of their party.

Since I was very young, I have dreamed of the time when human beings would go into space. The test pilots - the Mercury and Gemini crews - were among the bravest ever; the Apollo crews received far less attention than they deserved (except for one) and the moon landings were wonderful, intense, and grieved when they ended.

For years, people saw the Shuttle as... kind of boring. (Not I.) And then, because of the kind of criticism that followed the accidents, too dangerous. (Good thing Columbus never sank a ship. Oh, wait. He did.) And then the cry became "too expensive" and my heart sank, because whenever someone starts harping on that tune... dreams die.

This interview has renewed my hope that the United States of America -- that, indeed, the world -- has not given up on the dream, and is working diligently and intelligently and thoughtfully to put human beings in space, where they belong. And that we're doing it as a PLANET, rather than just as one country.

And maybe one day *I* can go out there... I'll try to keep myself in shape so I'll be ready. Even if I'm 101.

Thanks again - just read the article, can't wait for the video. xo R

Deciding whether to be a parent is 100% emotional (at least for me), which seems counter-intuitive, given the magnitude and the consequences of the decision. I married at 26, was never really into kids, and wasn't sure I wanted them. When I thought I was pregnant for a couple of weeks in the first year of our marriage, the only emotion I felt was panic, followed by immense relief when I discovered that I wasn't...My husband and I spent our time building our careers, traveling, and running a lot of marathons.

When discussing my ambivalence with my mother (who was a SAHM to four of us), she pointed out that deciding to have a child is completely irrational. It makes sense: think about what you give up to have a child. You take a HUGE income hit. Most women will probably have to make some career sacrifices. You will never sleep the same again. Traveling options become limited to Disneyland. You get fat. Your alone time is nonexistent...My childless self thought parents were boring and privately felt sorry for them for not having the freedom my husband and I had.

One day, I woke up and wanted to be a mother. Just like that. And it all happened very quickly. My husband and I became parents just over five years into our marriage when I was 32 and he was 38. The experience of being a parent is indescribable.

The only regret I feel now is for those who feel the way I used to feel. I want to shake them and yell, "You don't know what you're missing!" Again, completely irrational.

Regretting the loss of your childless lifestyle is different than regretting the existence of your children. I regret not being able to run marathons anymore or read a novel in an afternoon, but my daughter is the joy of my life. Admittedly, I didn't have to deal with an unplanned pregnancy when my husband and I were having our childfree fun, and I never had to deal with difficulties in getting pregnant, so my regrets are few in that sense.

I say, go with your gut. But if you do have a child, odds are you won't regret it.

I wouldn't only blame the interest groups. I would blame the clueless economists who wouldn't shoot down the idea of austerity and propose debt relief for the public sector.

Why hasn't ANY mainstream economist predicted the crisis? Because they haven't paid attention to private debt. On the other hand, they tend to get hysterical about the public debt which is always a much smaller problem.

Ostensibly we need to fear the public debt because it is "like a household debt, only bigger". In fact, it is OPPOSITE to a household debt: without federal IOUs (dollars, bonds) the public would have NO net savings! I can have a deposit in the bank, but this is bank's liability. To hold savings in aggregate, the private sector needs to hold IOUs of someone outside it. This someone is the government issuing its IOUs. Private net savings is holding government debt (dollars, bonds). No federal debt, no net savings for the private sector.

Imagine a Monopoly game. The central banker wants to "be responsible" and run a surplus - take in more dollars than he emits, thus siphoning off the players' savings. The game will stall, the Monopoly economy will die. This "plan" is backed by neoliberal theories that defy basic accounting: supposedly this will make the players "more confident in the government" and spend more (Spend what? - they have less money now, go figure. And: when was the last time you thought about federal budget before spending? I just look at my income: the federal IOUs in my wallet, the more the better!).

But if the govt keeps spending, the US will go bankrupt, right? Wrong. The reason is because the US is off the gold standard, it creates every dollar it spends out of thin air (unlike Greece that needs to borrow Euros to spend). Gold could run out and the government could go bankrupt, but now the US creates money as needed with each payment and it destroys (almost) the same amount by taxing. If you are thinking "what about inflation?!" - you are right. The only problem can be too much money (inflation), but the government cannot possibly run out of dollars, like a bowling alley cannot run out of points. Here is Bernanke stating that US is not spending taxpayers' money it had stashed away somewhere:
http://moslereconomics.com/2011/04/22/quick-bernanke-video-clip-from-60-...

Also: contrary to what most pundits claim the US can control the interest rates it pays: the Fed and not the market sets the rates. Again: poor Greece is different, think Japan instead: 200% debt/GDP and low interest rates. “Experts” have been predicting Japan's soaring rates, hyperinflation and bankruptcy for 20 years now, big yawn. The mainstream (unfortunately Paul Krugman included) doesn't understand the fundamental difference between Japan and Greece: Greece can simply run out of Euros, Japan cannot run out of Yen and it shows in the bond yields.

We should ask everyone harping about "excessive" federal debt:

Do you understand why paying off public debt each time resulted in a depression? It was tried 7 times, each with disastrous consequences.
http://www.newdeal20.org/2010/02/10/the-federal-budget-is-not-like-a-hou...

Why do you claim that public debt crowds out private savings? Accounting proves it's the opposite. Without federal bonds the public sector cannot net save.
http://bilbo.economicoutlook.net/blog/?p=1075
http://mosler2012.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/7deadly.pdf

Why would we quit playing the game regardless of the side of the Atlantic, Paul? Every day I read Republican deceit about our budget and economy. Each Sunday morning I listen to the usual Republican guests respond with the usual obfuscation to moderators on the "reality reporting shows" like Meet the Press. Most deny they're doing or have done what they are in fact doing and have done, or claim to be doing what they aren't and haven't done. Cantor? Pawlenty? McConnell? Boehner? Too many Republicans play the game of deceit, or what parent's call "lying" when their kids do it. "Rentiers?" You include their avatars, too, right?

An example: Pawlenty is correct in this sense about class warfare: Republicans have been blitzkrieging the middle class for 30 years.
1. Since Ronald Reagan Republicans repeatedly cut taxes, didn't balance our budget when they could, and borrowed and borrowed and borrowed. They amassed most of our national debt. They promised that deficits don't matter. National debt was $994 billion when Reagan entered office. George Walker Bush alone increased it from $5.7 trillion to $10.4 trillion. 91% of the $10.4 trillion debt Obama inherited is from Reagan, Bush I, and Bush II. Barack Obama also inherited wars in Iraq and in Afghanistan, a ruined economy, massive banking and financial bailouts, and slashed tax revenues that obligated government to a trillion dollars in additional debt.
2. Republican tax cuts and policy resulted in a transfer and concentration of wealth in the United States not seen since the Great Depression. By fourth quarter end 2010 U.S. household net worth totaled $56.8 trillion, 34% controlled by the top 1% of Americans and 73% controlled by the top 10%. 90% of income earned here is earned by the top tiers of wealthy Americans. Income and wealth disparity are the greatest they've been since 1929. Our poverty rate is at a 50 year high. More Americans than ever rely on government help to feed their families.
3. Middle class income has stagnated since 1973. National "median income" is $49,800.00. The bottom 90% of Americans average $31,000 a year in income.
4. Republican policy and governance gave us a collapsed economy and 13,700,000 unemployed Americans. 20% of workers are underemployed.

The U.S. fiscal collapse over the decades beginning with Ronald Reagan is about two things only: MONEY and POWER. There's plenty of money in the U. S.. Our current political arguments are just battles over allocation of that money. We may not be able to balance the budget only by "taxing the wealthy" as many Republicans wish to cast it, but our taxes are the lowest of western nations and our wealthy citizens and corporations are the least taxed they've been for 50 years. Hundreds of billions of dollars are in corporate coffers. It isn't the middle class that has power in the U.S. We're a Republic, a representative democracy, in which business and their lobbyists are more represented than individual voters.

Another example, why is it that we were willing, even in the midst of The Great Depression, to raise marginal tax rates to over 90%, and for 40 years to leave them over 70%, as we waged world and regional wars and built our truly great nation, but we won't raise them now to even 45% to wage war on debt, unemployment, bad education, health for all, and to restore our great nation? It isn't as if the wealthy will suffer. THEY HAVE NEARLY ALL THE MONEY. And THEY HAVE NEARLY ALL THE POWER. It's as if the owners of penthouses in a large condominium, who own roof top swimming pools, decide they don't like the HOA expense for one community pool for the other residents, and demand as members of the board that the HOA replace it with a toddlers wading pool those wealthy declare to be better. That's what Republicans propose for Medicare. It's what they intend for all our societal spending.

Once upon a time a scorpion, to cross a stream, got a ride on its promise to a frog to not sting. Half way across it did. When the paralyzed frog protested the scorpion responded that it had to sting, it's a scorpion's nature. If Republicans are allowed to replace Medicare with a program that favors their corporate benefactors then social security, unemployment compensation and disability are next. They'll call the changed institutions swimming pools. But they'll be waders. That's what Republicans do. It's their nature.

Lincoln said that, "You can fool some of the people all of the time and all of the people some of the time, but you can't fool all the people all the time." The warning is that you can fool people. Republicans count on it. It's their nature. We've become a government of, by, and for the wealthy and powerful, of "rentiers." What Republicans intend is what they promise: to shrink government until it's small enough that they can drown it in a wading pool. It's their nature. Quit playing the game indeed.

If anybody had any doubts that President Obama's administration works solely in the interest of the "rentiers" and the big banks, they were dispelled last week when he told House Democrats that he could and would do nothing about the lousy economy and unemployment for fear of disturbing "The Markets".

These markets are not even in the confines of the United States. They are the global banking cabal, the corporations, the almighty bond-holders. It's as though the economy of Wall Street trumps the economy of a nation, even the economy of the world. There are the markets, and then there are the rest of us. You know -- people.

And as Obama uses his "crisis of confidence" excuse, let's use the other definition of confidence -- as in, confidence game run by confidence tricksters. These financial manipulators have exploited the collective psyche of the globe, preying upon the naivete, political and economic self-interest and vanity of our elected officials, who depend upon them for their own survival. This criminal financial cabal has managed to convince governments of imminent monetary Armageddon should the markets be regulated, unemployment addressed, mortgage fraud investigated, banksters prosecuted and jailed.

They are holding our own government hostage and we in turn are being held hostage by a weak and/or complicit President. We can blame Timothy Geithner all we want, but in the end it's Obama who picked him and who is now refusing to fire him. All the populist economists abandoned ship. Geithner is not even an economist. He is a big bank hack.

We all know the right wing Tea Partiers are crazy, but the craziness has even infected those who we all thought were the "good guys." The next meltdown is coming. We see it coming and we are paralyzed. The real crisis is the tragic and utter lack of leadership, anywhere.

Paul Krugman is right when he argues that one could hire additional workers at government expense to build up education and infrastructure economy with little cost to the overall economy. After all, much of the work would be done by people who would otherwise be unemployed. Unemployment is a drag on the economy because much of the spare capacity for labor just gets wasted.

He is also correct that homeowners need some relief from the steady stream of foreclosures. Here Obama had some good ideas which were abandoned, such as allowing bankruptcy court to lower mortgages that are underwater. This would of course have a negative impact on the banking sector, but it baffles me why banking has so much political clout, why we cannot hold banking responsible for the CDO's and other instruments of financial destruction they created.

Krugman is less convincing when he argues for higher inflation. The argument that this helps debtors only works only if the debtors can demand higher wages to offset increased costs, something which is not so possible when unemployment is high. Inflation in commodities is particularly troublesome when it drives up food prices, which people need to survive. About 44 million Americans are now on food stamps, and inflation together with high unemployment is a toxic mix for many.

And roughly half of the national debt is owned by foreigners who would likely regard any intentional policy to set a higher inflation target as tantamount to a default by the US on its obligations. The only thing saving the US from higher interest rates is the fact that the major competing currency---the euro---has even greater problems with the potential bankruptcies of Greece, Ireland and Portugal. And although interest rates are so low now that real yields on 10-year treasuries are close to zero, and negative after taxes, continued deficits of $1.5 trillion per year are not sustainable.

That's why economic stimulus---jobs for the unemployed---should be payed for by higher top rates on the wealthy. Sadly, on all the important economic issues---more stimulus, mortgage relief, higher taxes to pay down the deficit---Obama has caved to the Republicans. We voted for FDR but got another reincarnation of Bush.

In the current political economy, several forces are in play against job growth. Culturally, the GOP continues to be the small party with the Big Story driving the political and policy discussions. The story's purpose also has multiple purposes; the main one being to hide the expansion of GOP command and control revenue and power through the budget process. Under the big tent idea of deficit reduction, the GOP plan to cut taxes for the rich, restrict environmental regulation, shrink rights for women, workers, bind education, and transfer public monies to expand wealth, with medicare being the GOP's starring idea of how to shrink benefits and expand revenues for the wealthy. But on the way to deconstructing a popular program, which, under the GOP, would be called Medicare—after the program formerly known as Medicare--its essence would be different. Keeping the name is merely a charade, as insulting as the clip art proposal they presented as a jobs proposal. Clip art does not create jobs.

In the new qualitative construct, the old assumptions and relations are being reworked. Even the focus on these new relationships is being redirected away from their real intent. If you can borrow at zero interest, why not borrow? If you can create economic expansion through electronic trading globally, why not expand profits? If you can build wealth through markets in currency, commodities, equities, and special instruments, why not? The more interesting question is why not one CEO of the 1,000 largest corporations has been called for an interview and asked about jobs. Only pundits repeating the big story of fear as the shock wave of policy are being interviewed. Yet wealth is hoarded under our noses. In fact, the Times has recently featured a series of op-ed posts featuring sympathetic looks at the problems plaguing global billionaires! And why has not one CEO been interviewed in print or broadcast media and asked about their job creation strategy the growth and expansion of their human resources?

The global company, Rio Tinto, just pledged to buy a billion dollars of commodities in the next year from China, and China's state managed economy is building mines and farms in Brazil and Africa. None of this activity is possible without the low interest rate leverage that makes the investment of big sums attractive. BP still has contracts with the Defense Department worth more then 10+ billion dollars annually. The top 100 US government contractors all benefit from not having to increase productivity to keep up with the cost of money. As long as interest rates stay near zero and interest risks are non-existent, why not exploit the mega-markets for capital and abandon workers? No one's asking or holding corporate heads accountable or putting them in the spotlight.

I fear the fate of the American worker, now abandoned by both parties. Especially as clip art and imaginary fears are the drivers of policies for “job growth.” Once a worker nation that attracted millions and paid fair wages, we are now the corporate state that makes billions, interest free, on the backs of the of unemployed.
--Walter Rhett

Bravo, Dr. Krugman! You're one of the few influential people who isn't dictated by Rentiers. In a world where the stench of greed and corruption permeate, your column is a whiff of fresh air.

The prevailing mindset among our policymakers is bizarre, to say the least. There appears to be a fixation with inflation, the value of currency and austerity, before even addressing the more immediate problems of unemployment and feeble economic growth. An incomprehensibly mad rush to put the carriage before the horse.

You are correct to point out who are behind this Pain Caucus. It's the big players. The banks, the hedge funds, the insurance companies and other financial institutions which have a huge stake in the stability of the bond and currency markets.

Ironically, these institutions are also the big players in the commodities market. Positions they take have caused huge volatility in those markets.

Hedge funds have been identified as the primary culprits behind the huge swings in oil, metals and agricultural products, oftentimes bringing about artificial shortages or gluts, depending on what positions they take. It wasn't too long ago when Goldman Sachs spooked the world by declaring that $300 per barrel oil was just around the corner.

Sadly, what I gather from this kind of mindset is that human capital is of very little value to those who influence opinion and policy. It has all been reduced to financial terms. Fiscal restraint is more important than human lives and human dignity. Deficit reduction is more important than creating or saving jobs. The value of money takes precedence over humanity.

Thank you, Dr. Krugman, for being a sane voice in a world gone mad. I can only hope that, with voices such as yours, the world will one day wake up from this demented, suicidal frame of mind.

Professor, let's not forget that Rentiers also profit from volatility in the commodities markets. The wild swings in oil and metals are often manipulated by hedge funds and cartels. So they have it both ways.

Logic and reason have been usurped by power, greed and ideology. Corporations/wealthy pull the strings and game the system to benefit themselves at the expense of everyone else. As long as they are earning their profits or maintaining their subsidies/tax cuts/loopholes why change anything. The profit mentality trumps all regardless of the consequences.

Rentiers may play some part for setting the world agenda, but I’m convinced it’s a group far more powerful, namely the major banks, Wall St. investment firms/holding companies and giant global corporations like GE and even the M.I.C.

Interest rates are at an historical lows. These firms can borrow at basically no cost and then speculate to their hearts content. They know their governments will be the final backstop if something goes awry. Think of it as unlimited credit line where you can buy anything at fire sale prices. A worldwide depression means exponential buying opportunities for those that have the where-with-all. With essentially no market/security risk, their upside is unlimited.

If employment around the world increases in these depressed economies, this will change the dynamics of the income model, as it will put upward pressure on interest rates. Thus, the cost of borrowing will increase and decrease their profits margins. Also, with higher interest rates, the dollar will become stronger and when their funds are repatriated, they will lose even more money.

Keeping interest rate low will eventually create another bubble just as when Greenspan kept them low too long. We’ve seen what happens in 2008 when rampant speculation without regulations destroys our economies and markets. Be prepared for the next bubble burst. Be afraid, be very afraid that governments may not be able to handle or fully recover from the next debacle.

Yes, Wall Street and the investor class practically own the WH and the leadership of both major parties. Geithner has been even more of a deficit hawk than Obama, although Obama's twelve-year austerity program is bad enough for the hopes of a recovery from the current recession. Cutting deficits during a recession is economic madness and is an idea that serves only big finance and financial institutions such as the IMF, which are fixated solely on the goal of protecting their loans and investments, no matter what the damage is to the local economy. Though both Republicans and the WH claim otherwise, budget cutting during a recession tanks the economy, dampens demand, lowers revenues, and increases the deficit. History shows that -- except for countries with a big export surplus, which definitely excludes the US -- during a recession only an expansion of government spending and the creation of more jobs and demand can entice companies to produce more and increase revenues, thus cutting the deficit.

Since more temporary, well targeted government spending is the proven way to reduce unemployment and shrink the deficit, the financial class is actually making things worse for ordinary people and shrinking not the deficit but the middle class as a whole. Special payments to ordinary families, such as those made in Australia, would stimulate the economy more than continued bailouts of and cheap money for big finance, and Australian unemployment levels have been much lower than ours, probably because of this spread-the-wealth policy. But Wall Street and the rest of the investor class in the US do not seem willing to spread the wealth around. They want to keep almost all the money flowing between banks so that they can try to pay down their hidden debts and pretend that they have completely recovered from the meltdown, and they would rather foreclose on homeowners than renegotiate mortgage terms. Meanwhile, manufacturing firms are making profits by increasing productivity while not passing along the gains in the form of wage increases or more jobs. Wages and working conditions deteriorate as the number of unemployed increases.

The WH and Dem leadership is not responding to this worsening crisis of unemployment and weak demand. If the president and the Dems in Congress hope to win in 2012, they must stop working for Wall Street and the financial class and propose ways to stimulate the economy, which is falling back into what may well turn into a double-dip recession. The best single way to do this would be to propose a contemporary permanent WPA that would expand during recessions and shrink during good times. A new, permanent WPA would do away with the need for unemployment insurance and related programs, and it would contribute to protecting the recovery and cutting the deficit, so it would be comparatively cheap and fiscally responsible, while protecting the lives and livelihoods of millions of Americans. Mr. President, are you listening?
